intro: Elaphoglossum erinaceum var. boliviensis, commonly known as the Bolivian holly fern, is a rare and delicate fern species native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Blechnaceae and is characterized by its finely divided, holly-like leaves that are often covered in a dense, velvety coating. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist environments such as cloud forests, where it thrives in cool, humid conditions. Its spores are produced in specialized structures called sorus, which are located on the underside of the fronds. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species, making it of interest to botanists and conservationists alike.
